en: Interview with Mona Papeş, a professor with the Ecology and Evolutionary Biology College at the University of Tennessee. Papeş discusses her research in the Smokies concerning the collection of data to support multiple projects across a longterm period of time. This is a representative quote from the interview: "We are seeing some invasive species, those species that are not native to the Smoky Mountains. We are finding some, but we expected we would be seeing more invaders. It seems, based on just 2 years--2 1/2 years of data, it seems that the communities are quite resilient."

Interview with Mona Papeş, a professor with the Ecology and Evolutionary Biology College at the University of Tennessee. Papeş discusses her research in the Smokies concerning the collection of data to support multiple projects across a longterm period of time. This is a representative quote from the interview: "We are seeing some invasive species, those species that are not native to the Smoky Mountains. We are finding some, but we expected we would be seeing more invaders. It seems, based on just 2 years--2 1/2 years of data, it seems that the communities are quite resilient."

Interview with Mona Papeş, 2020-02-21 -- Great Smoky Mountains National Park
How long have you lived in East Tennessee?
Could you talk about your career path in coming here?
So you joined UT in Spring 2017?
What was your research area before the fire?
Could you describe the communication during the time of the fire?
How did things look when you got to East Tennessee?
Can you describe your piece of the research?
It sounds like your research is the foundation for the other subjects and nedds flexibility in the field?
How would you describe people's response to your work?
Do you think that losing sites due to vegetation growth has anything to do with the fire?
After identifying the plots, what is the next step in the research process?
How much time does it take at one plot to count and identify each plant species that is present?
How often do you visit each plot?
What are some of the results and finding from this research?
What do you see for the future of this research and what opportunities are there?
How do you see this research ehlping the public to understand what happened and what could potentially happen?

seo.title: Interview with Mona Papeş, 2020-02-21 - Rising From the Ashes Oral Histories

This is a representative quote from the interview: "We are seeing some invasive species, those species that are not native to the Smoky Mountains. We are finding some, but we expected we would be seeing more invaders. It seems, based on just 2 years--2 1/2 years of data, it seems that the communities are quite resilient."
